audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a male speaker giving "greetings from Sierra Leone and the Maternal Center of Excellence" with a friendly tone. He continues, describing the "48,000 square foot maternal and infant care center currently being built in Sierra Leone" and reflecting on "how many lives are being helped by our little online community" with a somewhat emotional tone, followed by "let me back up".

The audio clip starts with a male speaker describing the transformation of the maternity ward at Koidu Government Hospital in Sierra Leone, contrasting its current state with its conditions eight years prior. He speaks in an informative tone about the improvements made in healthcare, while also noting existing inadequacies in the system. He emphasizes the need for further improvements, stating, "It's simply not acceptable." The speaker underscores that they don't have to accept the current situation. The clip concludes with a distinct "ding" sound.

The audio begins with a male speaker discussing the Maternal Center of Excellence. He mentions fundraising efforts and describes the envisioned world-class healthcare center in Kono. He expresses the difficulty of conveying the scale of the project, noting ongoing construction work and a timeline for the opening of the first wards. The tone is informative and enthusiastic.

A male speaker is talking about a nurse-midwife and an engineer working together, noting the engineer has "a phenomenal Sharpie hat," in a conversational tone. This transitions into the sound of a bell.

A male speaker discusses a center of excellence, detailing maternal care and neonatal intensive care units, specifying the capacity for emergency C-sections. He notes it will be a teaching hospital to train midwives, nurses, and doctors. He mentions visiting the site for dormitories and staff housing and then lightheartedly describes young boys watching big machines.

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing how people working on a construction site have been trained in new skills. His tone is informative and somewhat conversational. He mentions that some training comes from classes and, surprisingly, from "educational YouTube videos." This is followed by musical sounds that may be for background purposes.

The clip starts with a male speaker expressing a light-hearted sentiment about "YouTube University on the TV." This is followed by a segment featuring a male voice narrating an observation that a significant percentage of construction workers are women. The narrator proceeds to quote one of the women, who speaks about how her life has changed, and how she feels differently about herself. She expresses pride and notes that she has realized that the skills she's learning aren't just for today but for the future. She also mentions how unusual it is for people to see women doing construction. Another woman speaks briefly about her experience of learning to weld. Finally, a woman speculates on why so many women are working at the MCOE, mentioning a desire to give back to the community in the future. Ambient sounds of construction are present in the background throughout this part.

The clip begins with a female speaker discussing building a hospital, followed by a male speaker clarifying that improvements to maternal and child health are not solely dependent on new buildings. He details ongoing training for medical personnel and efforts to identify high-risk pregnancies. The male speaker emphasizes a special care baby unit's significant impact on reducing child mortality. A female speaker then says that the goal is to provide continuous access to babies for mothers and to enable feeding on demand.

A male speaker discusses a special care baby unit, explaining how it has improved survival rates and highlighting the unit's challenges, such as difficult admission decisions and the need for constant resources and maintenance to function effectively, emphasizing that it's more than just providing equipment. The speaker maintains a serious and informative tone.

The clip begins with a male speaker expressing the positive impact of providing necessary support, stating "this unit is thriving." He continues, acknowledging monthly donors and those who've made one-time gifts or shared the project, emphasizing, "this is the change you're making." The overall tone is enthusiastic and appreciative.

The clip begins with a male speaker stating "two years ago the parents of almost all of these kids would have gone home heartbroken". His tone is reflective and somewhat somber. He then continues with a more positive tone, describing the "dignified high quality healthcare" coming to Kona and with it, "generational change". The clip features only this single speaker.

The audio clip starts with a speaker, a male, discussing fundraising and mentions that they still need to raise "just over $10 million" to support healthcare. He encourages monthly donations or one-time gifts through a website and large gifts through a special link or email, ending with gratitude for attention. The speech is conversational and friendly. Following this, there's the sound of music in the background.

The clip starts with a male speaker reflecting on a project's lessons, emphasizing that collective attention improves problem-solving. A second male speaker then recalls a specific situation in a special care baby unit, where co-founder Ophelia Dahl inquired about the survival chances of a frail baby on a CPAP machine.

The audio begins with a female speaker stating, "All these babies are going to live." She continues in an excited tone, mentioning "the good news room," expressing pride in the "Koidu Government Hospital," and acknowledging Marie, Hawa, Success, and others from the Maternal Center of Excellence. Her speech suggests more positive outcomes are expected. A male speaker follows, marveling at what humans can accomplish when united, and concludes by confirming a meeting on Friday.
